channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Beijing Was Confident Its Hong Kong Allies Would Win. After the Election, It Went Silent.
item.description: Since the big loss for the pro-Beijing camp, Chinese state media has resorted to a favorite tactic by blaming the United States, a nationalistic message that plays well to the masses at home.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movement celebrating on the streets outside a polling station in Tuen Mun, Hong Kong, early Monday.

item.title: A Montreal Bagel War Unites Rival Kings
item.description: A culinary symbol of Montreal has become ensnared in a battle pitting environmentalists against bagel-loving traditionalists.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Chris Wattie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fresh bagels being removed from a wood-burning oven at Fairmount Bagel, a Montreal institution.

item.title: Albania Earthquake Kills at Least 23
item.description: The 6.4-magnitude quake, one of the strongest to hit the country in decades, struck near Tirana, the capital. Hundreds of injuries were reported.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Iliana Magra and Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Emergency workers cleared debris after a building collapsed in Thumane. As the Albanian authorities requested international assistance, Montenegro and Serbia sent support and rescue teams.

item.title: U.K. Chief Rabbi Denounces Labour Party on Anti-Semitism
item.description: The rabbi, Ephraim Mirvis, suggested the opposition party’s leader, Jeremy Corbyn, was “unfit for office,” adding that Britain’s soul was at stake in next month’s election.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Chief Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis called Labour’s claim to be fully addressing anti-Semitism in its ranks “a mendacious fiction.”

item.title: 3 Afghan Schools, 165 Accounts of Students Being Raped
item.description: An advocacy group says it has documented systematic sexual abuse by teachers, principals and other authorities of dozens of boys in one rural area.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Fatima Faizi
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The accusations in Logar Province, pictured above in 2018, point to a stunning breakdown in a relatively concentrated area.

item.title: Helicopter Crash in Mali Kills 13 French Troops
item.description: The midair collision of two helicopters was the deadliest incident in decades for the French military. The troops were part of a French force combating Islamist extremists.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: French soldiers during an operation to clear insurgents in Mali in 2017.

item.title: New Zealand Is Tackling Hot-Button Liberal Issues in One Swoop
item.description: The country will decide whether to legalize assisted suicide and recreational marijuana, and whether to decriminalize abortion. Conflict-averse New Zealanders may be pushed onto uncomfortable ground.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Graham-McLay
item.media:credit: Cornell Tukiri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hemp plant in Ruatoria, New Zealand. A referendum next year could legalize the recreational use of marijuana in the country.

item.title: Royal Jewels of ‘Immeasurable’ Value Are Stolen From a German Museum
item.description: Artifacts including diamonds, rubies and sapphires, said to be of immeasurable historical value, were taken from a display room in Dresden.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Christopher F. Schuetze

item.title: Death of Colombian Teenager Drives Protesters Back to Streets
item.description: Dilan Cruz, 18, died after being struck by a police projectile. Activists call him a symbol of “a generation that was robbed of its rights.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Students placing a Colombian flag on Tuesday at the site where Dilan Cruz was fatally wounded in Bogotá.

item.title: Iran Strengthens Response to Protests
item.description: The authorities say “six main elements” of unrest in Tehran were arrested. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he had received nearly 20,000 videos and other evidence from Iran of a violent suppression.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo speaking with reporters in Washington on Tuesday. Last week he asked Iranians to send evidence that protests had been violently suppressed during an internet blackout.

item.title: Sweden Investigates Iraq Defense Chief for War Crimes and Fraud
item.description: Iraq’s defense minister is under investigation for crimes against humanity and for claiming Swedish social benefits while he was living in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Christina Anderson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Najah al-Shammari, center, Iraq’s defense minister, at a security check point last month.

item.title: Pompeo Warns China to Honor ‘Human Rights Standards’ in Hong Kong
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo did not explicitly endorse legislation to support pro-democracy activists from Chinese-backed crackdowns, but noted standards that Beijing should heed.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: “We have human rights standards that we apply all across the world, and Hong Kong is no different,” Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said at a news conference at the State Department on Tuesday.

item.title: Albania’s Earthquake: What We Know so Far
item.description: Hundreds injured, buildings toppled and many trapped in the rubble as the small Balkan nation tried to assess the damage.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A new climate change report, a push for legal marijuana in New Zealand and the most influential films of the decade.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon

item.title: U.S. Envoy Says Afghans Coerced Retraction of Rape Allegations
item.description: Ambassador John R. Bass says the Afghan spy agency used “Soviet-style tactics.”
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Fatima Faizi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Teacher, an Artist, a Scientist and More. They’re All Visionaries.
item.description: The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries in their fields, from business and technology to culture and sports.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Saudi Arabia Is Stepping Up Crackdown on Dissent, Rights Groups Say
item.description: At least eight people have been arrested this month, some of whom had not expressed criticism of the government in years, the groups said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A screen with pictures of King Salman of Saudi Arabia, right, and the crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, in Riyadh.

item.title: Impeachment, Amazon, Albania: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Measles Cases Continue to Rise Around the World
item.description: Nearly a quarter of a million people in the Democratic Republic of Congo are thought to have been infected by measles in 2019 alone, the World Health Organization said.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A measles immunization campaign in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 2016.

item.title: Lured by Deep Powder, Foreigners Are Investing in the Aspen of Japan
item.description: With some 49 feet of snow a year, Niseko in northern Japan has become a ski playground for East Asians and Australians.
item.dc:creator: Tim Hornyak

item.title: ‘Bleak’ U.N. Report on a Planet in Peril Looms Over New Climate Talks
item.description: Countries agreed to rein in emissions in an effort to avert climate catastrophes. They've failed, according to the latest United Nations report.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A gas flare at a Shell refinery in Norco, La.

item.title: Skiing in Bulgaria? The Surprising Lure of the Balkans
item.description: A resort area that offers skiing, hot springs, mountain biking and horseback riding, and property at surprisingly low prices.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel Leigh
item.media:credit: Nikolay Doychinov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Govedartsi, Bulgaria. The area’s mountains form the highest peaks in the Balkans.

item.title: Uber, Spain, Thanksgiving: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Taiwan Detains 2 Executives of Firm Accused of Spying for China
item.description: The executives were detained as officials look into accusations that the company’s workers intervened in Taiwan’s looming national election campaign.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Chris Horton
item.media:description: The building listed as the address of China Innovation Investment Limited in Hong Kong on Saturday.

item.title: Alibaba’s Hong Kong Shares Rise, Despite Protests
item.description: The Chinese e-commerce giant raised $11.2 billion, the territory’s biggest tally since 2010, showing investor enthusiasm despite worsening demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: At work at Alibaba’s headquarters in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: 2 Priests Convicted in Argentina of Sexual Abuse of Deaf Children
item.description: The priests at a now-shuttered school in Mendoza were each sentenced to more than 40 years in prison; a former gardener was sentenced to 18 years.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Some of the victims who accused the priests of sexual abuse celebrated on Monday after learning the court’s verdict.

item.title: Rabbi Henry Sobel, 75, Dies; Defied Brazil’s Military Rulers
item.description: The leader of the largest liberal Jewish congregation in Latin America, he took a stand when a journalist was killed by his torturers in 1975.
item.dc:creator: Matt Sandy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nilton Fukuda/Agencia Estado, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rabbi Henry Sobel in 2013 at his home in the Higienopolis neighborhood of São Paulo. He led the largest liberal Jewish congregation in Latin America.

item.title: Peru Court Frees Keiko Fujimori From Preliminary Detention
item.description: Peru’s Constitutional Tribunal approved a habeas corpus request to the free opposition leader Keiko Fujimori from preliminary detention while she is investigated for alleged corruption.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Koalas Aren’t Extinct, but Their Future Is in Danger, Experts Say
item.description: Claims that koalas were “functionally extinct” spread widely online as fires raged in Australia. But some scientists warned of the dangers of exaggeration.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: A dehydrated and injured koala received treatment at the Port Macquarie Koala Hospital this month after it was rescued from a bush fire on Australia’s east coast.

item.title: On Day to End Violence Against Women, Spain’s Far Right Champions Men
item.description: Fresh from a strong showing at the polls, members of the ultranationalist Vox party have called for the repeal of a law that protects women from violence.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Madrid on Monday to mark the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women.

item.title: Hong Kong, ISIS, Julian Assange: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Kannapell

item.title: Truck Driver Pleads Guilty to 2 Charges in Essex Deaths
item.description: The 25-year-old, one of three people charged after dozens of Vietnamese were found dead in a refrigerated truck in Britain last month, faces 41 additional counts.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.category: Central Criminal Court of England and Wales (Old Bailey)
item.media:description: The scene where 39 people were found dead in a tractor-trailer in Essex, east of London, last month.

item.title: Julian Assange ‘Could Die’ in U.K. Jail, Doctors Warn
item.description: More than 60 physicians signed a letter saying that the WikiLeaks founder might not survive until February unless he receives an urgent expert medical assessment.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: Julian Assange after the British police arrested him at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in April.

item.title: France Announces New Measures to Tackle Domestic Violence
item.description: Advocacy groups welcomed a surge of awareness, but said the government’s proposals did not go far enough, and were not supported with nearly enough money.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Hong Kong Election Landslide Signals More Frictions With Beijing
item.description: Democracy supporters were emboldened by capturing most of the seats in local elections, but Beijing and its allies are reluctant to compromise.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Counting votes of the Hong Kong district council elections at a polling station in the Tuen Mun neighborhood on Sunday.

item.title: Scientists Created Fake Rhino Horn. But Should We Use It?
item.description: Experts are divided over whether flooding the Asian market with convincing artificial rhino horn would help or hurt rhinos’ survival.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.media:description: An African black rhino in the Singita Grumeti Game Reserve in Tanzania. Africa’s rhino population is about 24,500 animals, but poaching remains a threat.

item.title: Michael Bloomberg, Hong Kong, Tiffany: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Uber Is Fighting to Survive in London After Losing Its License
item.description: The company is at odds with regulators and drivers of traditional cabs in its most lucrative European market.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Amie Tsang
item.media:description: Uber’s offices in London. The company said it would appeal a decision not to extend its license in the city, setting off what could be a long legal process.

item.title: Pope Francis, in Japan, Warns of ‘Selfish Decisions’ on Nuclear Energy
item.description: Making the first visit to the country by a pope in 38 years, Francis called for an end to the nuclear arms race in visits to Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

item.title: Meet 5 of Hong Kong’s Newest Politicians
item.description: The pro-democracy camp’s stunning victory in citywide district elections means a younger class of political neophytes will soon take office.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-democracy winning candidates outside the campus of Hong Kong Polytechnic University on Monday.

item.title: Suicides by K-Pop Stars Prompt Soul-Searching in South Korea
item.description: Two beloved female stars, Sulli and Goo Hara, ended their own lives in two months, exposing the painful side of being a K-pop idol.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Su-Hyun Lee
item.media:description: A memorial altar paying homage to the K-pop star Goo Hara at the Seoul St. Mary's Hospital in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday.

item.title: Why Giuliani Singled Out 2 Ukrainian Oligarchs to Help Look for Dirt
item.description: Inside a strategy to leverage damaging information on Joe Biden from foreign citizens who were politically powerful — and legally vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Jo Becker, Walt Bogdanich, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Dmitry Firtash, a Ukrainian energy tycoon facing criminal charges in the United States, says he was offered help with his legal problems during a meeting with two Giuliani associates.

item.title: American Aid Worker for U.N. Is Killed in Afghan Capital
item.description: The killing of the United Nations employee underscores the growing threat to aid workers at a time Afghanistan is in dire need of humanitarian assistance.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Afghan security workers at the site of an explosion in Kabul on Sunday.

item.title: Tiffany’s, Davis Cup, Tories: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Kannapell

item.title: Across Northern England, Labour’s ‘Red Wall’ Is Showing Cracks
item.description: As in America, Britain’s rust belt regions are turning to the right, possibly heralding a realignment in next month’s general election.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gloria De Piero, left, the outgoing Labour lawmaker for Ashfield, campaigning with Natalie Fleet, the candidate who hopes to replace her.

item.title: British Man and Filipino Woman Rescued From Kidnappers in Philippines
item.description: The husband and wife were rescued by soldiers after insurgents came under attack and abandoned the couple.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Filipino soldiers disembarking from an aircraft in Zamboanga, the Philippines, after battling Abu Sayyaf militants in February. The militant group has been blamed in many kidnappings.

item.title: Luis Lacalle Pou Leads in Tight Uruguay Election, but Ballot Counting Continues
item.description: The ruling leftist party appears to be on its way out after nearly 15 years, as slow economic growth drags down incumbents.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Luis Lacalle Pou of Uruguay’s National Party voting on Sunday in Canelones. His victory was a setback for leftists in the region.

item.title: Cargo Ship With Almost 15,000 Sheep Overturns Near Romania
item.description: A rescue operation was underway to save the animals in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri and Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Thirty-two sheep were rescued, including two that were in the water, officials said on Sunday.

item.title: Egypt Escalates Pressure on Last Major Independent News Site
item.description: Security forces raided the publication’s office, detaining three editors, the day after arresting another editor.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Kannapell

item.title: Hong Kong Election Results Give Democracy Backers Big Win
item.description: A surge in voting, especially by young people, allowed democracy advocates to win many more seats on local councils.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democracy supporters celebrating in Hong Kong on Sunday night outside a polling station.

item.title: Leaked China Files Show Internment Camps Are Ruled by Secrecy and Spying
item.description: A secret document reflects leaders’ struggle to manage Xinjiang sites swelling with Muslim detainees.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials have taken journalists and diplomats to visit this indoctrination camp in Xinjiang, China.

item.title: How an Unknown Female Senator Came to Replace the Bolivian President Evo Morales
item.description: Inside the scramble to fill the power vacuum and name a leader to guide the country out of political chaos.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Cesar Del Castillo
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evo Morales, the former president of Bolivia, during a visit to The New York Times bureau in Mexico City.

item.title: New Suspect Charged in Trafficking After Truck Deaths in Britain
item.description: Christopher Kennedy of Northern Ireland stands accused a month after the bodies of 39 Vietnamese were found in a refrigerated trailer in southern England.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: Police experts investigating the trailer where the bodies were found in Grays, England, in October.

item.title: Goo Hara, K-Pop Star of the Group Kara, Is Found Dead
item.description: The 28-year-old singer, known as Hara, was found in her home on Sunday in Seoul, South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Goo Hara embarked on a solo career in 2015 and also had some television and film roles.

item.title: Voters in Romania Reject Years of Scandals and Chaos
item.description: President Klaus Iohannis claimed victory as his challenger, Viorica Dancila, conceded.
item.dc:creator: Kit Gillet and Marc Santora
item.media:description: President Klaus Iohannis of Romania after casting his ballot in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday.
